snippet.textDisplay:
Major caveat not mentioned: “confirmed case” doesn’t = bad case. Confirmed cases can also be asymptomatic cases, meaning the entire graph is nonsense in regards to policy and decision making. We don’t want confirmed cases to stop, we want everyone to be exposed and recover... all the graph shows is a fall-off in testing, not the spread. It makes sense that the people who are susceptible to this particular virus will fall seriously ill early on and then that number of people will abruptly decline because they’ve all been exposed and either died or recovered, NOT because a government hit a magical “eject button” and made up a policy. That’s “natural selection” in progress... a virus sweeps through a population, those who are susceptible get sick, those who aren’t continue unaffected... not because of a policy but because of biology. Nothing we’re doing is going to have any affect on the relationship between this virus and the human population. You can hide inside all you want, eventually everyone IS going to “get it” and the outcome will be the same. Not being heartless, just pointing out the obvious. If actual cases were on a graph it would be an exponential hockey stick all the way up to the total population #, then nothing. The graph is only plotting cases serious enough to warrant testing, not every possible carrier.
It’s a sensationalized doomsday graph. Reality says COVID 19 isn’t something to “beat”, it’s just another flu bug that will always be with us. Plotting only serious illness and deaths is great if your goal is to scare people. The vast majority of people will never even know they’ve been exposed, and probably already have been.
snippet.textOriginal:
Major caveat not mentioned: “confirmed case” doesn’t = bad case. Confirmed cases can also be asymptomatic cases, meaning the entire graph is nonsense in regards to policy and decision making. We don’t want confirmed cases to stop, we want everyone to be exposed and recover... all the graph shows is a fall-off in testing, not the spread. It makes sense that the people who are susceptible to this particular virus will fall seriously ill early on and then that number of people will abruptly decline because they’ve all been exposed and either died or recovered, NOT because a government hit a magical “eject button” and made up a policy. That’s “natural selection” in progress... a virus sweeps through a population, those who are susceptible get sick, those who aren’t continue unaffected... not because of a policy but because of biology. Nothing we’re doing is going to have any affect on the relationship between this virus and the human population. You can hide inside all you want, eventually everyone IS going to “get it” and the outcome will be the same. Not being heartless, just pointing out the obvious. If actual cases were on a graph it would be an exponential hockey stick all the way up to the total population #, then nothing. The graph is only plotting cases serious enough to warrant testing, not every possible carrier. 
It’s a sensationalized doomsday graph. Reality says COVID 19 isn’t something to “beat”, it’s just another flu bug that will always be with us. Plotting only serious illness and deaths is great if your goal is to scare people. The vast majority of people will never even know they’ve been exposed, and probably already have been.

snippet.textDisplay:
why is no one addressing the fact that there are a huge number of unconfirmed cases? anywhere between 25% and 75% of all cases are asymptomatic from start to end and do not show as confirmed because no tests are conducted.


Calculating cases requiring hospitalisations & fatality rates based on only confirmed cases is highly misleading and has started this panic.


Wouldn't it be helpful to inform the public that fatality rates are not 3% on average (and up to 8% in italy) but rather only 0.3 to 0.8%? 3 from 100 or 3 from 1000 dying would make a big difference in peoples minds.


Please demand information on that topic whenever in contact with people who know or should know because their deciding on our behalfs!

snippet.textDisplay: The data visualization needs a way to normalize the data to make the comparisons have some additional meaning, say plot new confirmed cases per thousand on one axis vs total confirmed cases per thousand on the other. It is nice to be able to step through time and see how it unfolds without normalization but a final snap shot of the latest data that is normalized will show how the countries responses have been successful relative to each other. If we do not do this with all other things being equal the smaller countries will tend to drop of the trajectory low on the graph while countries with larger populations will drop off the trajectory after climbing further. They should make this an option on the interactive chart. Once normalized it will scale up/down each country along the trajectory so we will be able to compare how the responses of each country have worked or not worked.
snippet.textOriginal: The data visualization needs a way to normalize the data to make the comparisons have some additional meaning, say plot new confirmed cases per thousand on one axis vs total confirmed cases per thousand on the other. It is nice to be able to step through time and see how it unfolds without normalization but a final snap shot of the latest data that is normalized will show how the countries responses have been successful relative to each other. If we do not do this with all other things being equal the smaller countries will tend to drop of the trajectory low on the graph while countries with larger populations will drop off the trajectory after climbing further. They should make this an option on the interactive chart. Once normalized it will scale up/down each country along the trajectory so we will be able to compare how the responses of each country have worked or not worked.

snippet.textDisplay: This still makes it seem as if 'beating the curve' means winning, it does not. It's only step 1. Once you're stabilized you have to keep that up until a decent % of the country is immune or a vaccine is produced. Like in Italy's case: Something like 5%, versus China's case: Something like 0.002%.  What I'd like to see next: Percentage of population infected versus rate of infection over time, annotated with measures taken. That might give insight into what measures you have to keep up for what time. Maybe weeks, maybe months, maybe years. Still really nice graph in the video though ;)
snippet.textOriginal: This still makes it seem as if 'beating the curve' means winning, it does not. It's only step 1. snippet.textDisplay:
I'd be really interested to see data regarding the change in death rate in afflicted countries. Particularly the death rate from medical causes (ie, excluding accidents, suicide/homicide, etc).
As you, and many others, have stated: we simply have no idea how many actual cases of coronavirus there are, and how many deaths can actually be attributed to it. There's quite a bit of speculation that coronavirus was already present and causing hospitalization or death months ago. If that is the case, it's not only possible but I would say likely that this virus has already infected a large number of people, much larger than we think. But because we're only testing those who we have reason to test (the people showing the most severe symptoms) we have drastically skewed data that is making us think things are much worse than they actually are.
When a pandemic like the 1918 flu strikes, the death rate spikes dramatically. Obviously. The number of people that are dying that wouldn't normally die is being elevated. The number of people having heart attacks, strokes, etc should be fairly constant, so if we see random, otherwise unexplained spikes in the overall death rate, and at the same time there is a pandemic sweeping humanity, that gives us a bit clearer of a look at things. We may not be able to test everyone for coronavirus or accurately attribute coronavirus to deaths, but even the most inefficient backwoods systems can generally tell you how many people have died during a certain period of time. If this number is spiking for no otherwise apparent reason, probably coronavirus.
I suspect we will see a slight elevation in deaths over the past few months. Coronavirus was setting in before anyone really cared. And I think it did start infecting people at an exponential rate, and we did start to see an exponential rise in deaths, but most people are able to fight it off like a common cold so no one really cared that much. It probably meant that people at high risk, ie the very old, the already sickly, and the most immuno-compromised, saw the highest death rates. But old people dying, pardon the callousness.... is not really news. Something was going to kill them, it turns out an extremely infectious but otherwise relatively mild contagion will do the trick. Once we noticed the trend, the alarms started to sound off and we became immensely focused. Even though we're quite likely well past the peak of infection, we only now start testing, and so to us this infection is "starting" to spread exponentially.
The rise in coronavirus cases probably has far more to do with measuring our ability to test for a disease than it does the actual presence and/or threat the disease poses. In short, stop buying toilet paper and stop panicking. But do wash your hands. Pandemic or not, that's just basic hygiene, don't be gross.

There's quite a bit of speculation that coronavirus was already present and causing hospitalization or death months ago. But because we're only testing those who we have reason to test (the people showing the most severe symptoms) we have drastically skewed data that is making us think things are much worse than they actually are.
When a pandemic like the 1918 flu strikes, the death rate spikes dramatically. Obviously. The number of people that are dying that wouldn't normally die is being elevated. The number of people having heart attacks, strokes, etc should be fairly constant, so if we see random, otherwise unexplained spikes in the overall death rate, and at the same time there is a pandemic sweeping humanity, that gives us a bit clearer of a look at things. We may not be able to test everyone for coronavirus or accurately attribute coronavirus to deaths, but even the most inefficient backwoods systems can generally tell you how many people have died during a certain period of time. If this number is spiking for no otherwise apparent reason, probably coronavirus.

And I think it did start infecting people at an exponential rate, and we did start to see an exponential rise in deaths, but most people are able to fight it off like a common cold so no one really cared that much. It probably meant that people at high risk, ie the very old, the already sickly, and the most immuno-compromised, saw the highest death rates. But old people dying, pardon the callousness.... is not really news. Something was going to kill them, it turns out an extremely infectious but otherwise relatively mild contagion will do the trick. Once we noticed the trend, the alarms started to sound off and we became immensely focused.
